letters.summary: Asquith writes from Syracuse, marveling at the Greek ruins but complaining about the stifling heat and the constant presence of their travel companions preventing private conversation.
letters.excerpt: The columns of the temple stand like ghosts against this relentless blue sky. I would give all of antiquity for one hour alone with you.

pm_activities: Touring the Greek Theatre in Syracuse; lunch with the Violet and the party.
venetia_activities: Sightseeing with the group; sketching ruins.
meeting_reference: Yes, shared a carriage during the drive to the ruins.
pm_mood_witness: Violet noted he seemed distracted and eager to escape the formal itinerary.

diaries_summary.excerpt: Father is complaining about the dust, but I suspect he is just bored of the history lectures. Venetia looks splendid in white.

letters.summary: The PM vents his fury regarding the 'Marconi shares' folly committed by Lloyd George and Rufus Isaacs, fearing it may bring down the government.
letters.excerpt: They have been incredibly foolish. LG and Rufus are in a state of panic, and I am left to hold the umbrella over their heads while the storm breaks.

pm_activities: Drafting defense speeches; meeting with the Chief Whip.
venetia_activities: Lunching with friends; shopping in Bond Street.

politics.parliament: Debate on the Select Committee Report regarding Marconi.
politics.cabinet: Emergency discussion on how to handle the Opposition's vote of censure.

pm_mood_witness: Frances Stevenson (LG's diary): The PM was stern but surprisingly calm, unlike LG who is a nervous wreck.

diaries_summary.excerpt: LG thinks Asquith will stand by him, but the atmosphere is toxic. The Tories smell blood.
LG is terrified the PM will throw him to the wolves.

letters.summary: A brief logistical note confirming the car is ready for their weekly Friday drive, expressing relief at the prospect of escaping London.
letters.excerpt: The motor will be at the back gate at 4:30. For two hours, the world can look after itself and I shall be happy.

pm_activities: Morning work at the War Office; afternoon drive to the country.
pm_mood_witness: Margot Asquith: Henry left early for his drive; he seems to live for these Friday excursions.

diaries_summary.excerpt: I do not ask who he goes with, but he always returns looking refreshed.

letters.summary: Asquith describes a chaotic scene where a suffragette threw a bag of flour at him during a public appearance.
letters.excerpt: A wild-eyed creature lunged at me with a bag of flour. I am quite unharmed, but dignity is a little harder to recover when one looks like a baker.

letters.summary: A late-night follow-up expressing his weariness with the constant security threats and his longing for peace.
letters.excerpt: The flour is washed off, but the weariness remains. These women are relentless. I only wish for a quiet room and your voice.

pm_activities: Public speech at the Guildhall; meeting with Home Secretary regarding security.
pm_mood_witness: McKenna: The PM took the assault with good humor, but was clearly shaken later.

diaries_summary.excerpt: Papa came home covered in white dust. He made a joke of it, but it's getting dangerous.

letters.summary: Asquith asks for gossip from the 'Coterie' party at Stanway, feeling old and detached from the younger generation's hedonism.
letters.excerpt: Tell me what the 'Corrupt Coterie' is plotting. I feel like a ghost at the feast when I hear of your high spirits.

venetia_activities: Attending a costume party with The Coterie.
meeting_reference: No, Venetia is away at Stanway.
pm_mood_witness: Cynthia Asquith: The PM was asking many questions about who was at Stanway.

diaries_summary.excerpt: The Coterie was in full swing. We played charades until 3am. Venetia was the center of attention.

letters.summary: The Curragh Mutiny is unfolding. Asquith writes frantically about the recalcitrant generals and the threat of civil war in Ulster.
letters.excerpt: Seely has blundered. The Generals are threatening resignation. It is the gravest situation yet; the Army is asserting itself against Parliament.

pm_activities: Emergency meetings with Seely and French; managing the King's anxiety.

politics.parliament: Explosive questions regarding Army movements in Ulster.
politics.cabinet: Emergency Cabinet on the resignation of officers.

pm_mood_witness: Maurice Hankey: The PM is showing strain for the first time; his hands shook slightly holding the papers.

diaries_summary.excerpt: The Army vs. The People. Asquith is trying to bridge a gap that looks unbridgeable.

letters.summary: Morning note reporting the shocking news of the Larne gun-running incident where Ulster volunteers landed thousands of rifles.
letters.excerpt: They have landed 25,000 rifles at Larne. The police stood by and watched. It is open rebellion.

letters.summary: Mid-day letter venting frustration at the King's potential interference and the passivity of the Irish administration.
letters.excerpt: The King is agitated. Birrell is wringing his hands. I need to find a way to enforce the law without starting a civil war.

letters.summary: Late night note seeking solace after an exhausting day of crisis management.
letters.excerpt: The day has been a nightmare of telegrams and panic. I turn to you as the only calm point in a turning world.

pm_activities: Crisis meetings all day; audience with the King.
pm_mood_witness: Violet Asquith: Father is furiously angry with the Irish administration for letting this happen.

diaries_summary.excerpt: The Larne news is catastrophic. Father says it makes the government look impotent.

letters.summary: Asquith describes the expiration of the ultimatum to Germany, the silence in the Cabinet room, and the chiming of Big Ben signaling the start of the war.
letters.excerpt: It is all over. We are at war. The clock struck eleven and we sat in silence. I can only pray that we have done the right thing.

pm_activities: Waiting for the German reply; issuing orders for mobilization.
venetia_activities: Waiting for news at Downing Street (in the drawing room).
meeting_reference: Yes, Venetia was present in the house during the countdown.

politics.cabinet: Continuous session awaiting the ultimatum expiry.

pm_mood_witness: Margot Asquith: Henry sat staring out the window with tears in his eyes.

diaries_summary.excerpt: The die is cast. Winston is happy, the PM is grave, Lloyd George is silent.
I looked at Henry and saw the weight of the world settle upon him.

letters.summary: Asquith details the explosive conflict between Fisher and Churchill regarding the Dardanelles, feeling like a referee in a boxing match.
letters.excerpt: Fisher is sulking and threatens to leave; Winston is manic and pushing for the Dardanelles. I have to keep the peace between the old man and the young eagle.

pm_activities: War Council meeting; private mediation between Fisher and Churchill.

politics.cabinet: War Council: Decision taken to bombard the Dardanelles.

pm_mood_witness: Hankey: The PM was exhausted by the personalities involved.

diaries_summary.excerpt: Venetia writes to Edwin asking if Winston is really as mad as people say.

letters.summary: Asquith expresses his horror and fear at the idea of Venetia wearing a uniform and being exposed to disease and 'unsightly things' at the hospital.
letters.excerpt: I cannot bear to think of you scrubbing floors or tending to wounds. It is not your place. You are made for beauty, not for the gore of the ward.

pm_activities: Reviewing Army estimates; lunch with Margot.
venetia_activities: Attending nursing training course at London Hospital.
pm_mood_witness: Violet: Father is very irritable about Venetia's new 'hobby'.

diaries_summary.excerpt: Venetia is taking this nursing very seriously. Papa thinks it's a fad, but I think she wants to be useful.

letters.summary: The Times has attacked the government over the lack of shells. Asquith suspects Sir John French is feeding the press to cover his own failures.
letters.excerpt: Northcliffe is out for blood. The headlines are screaming that our men are dying for lack of high explosives. It is a calculated blow.

pm_activities: Crisis meeting with Kitchener; drafting rebuttal to the press.
venetia_activities: Secretly meeting Edwin Montagu to discuss engagement.

politics.cabinet: Kitchener defends the War Office supply lines.

pm_mood_witness: Frances Stevenson: LG is very quiet, watching the PM struggle with the Northcliffe press.

diaries_summary.excerpt: The government is shaking. The Shells issue might be the final straw.

letters.summary: The devastating letter where Asquith reacts to the news that Venetia is marrying Edwin Montagu. He declares he is 'quite alone'.
letters.excerpt: This is the end. To think that you, of all people, would leave me for him. I am quite alone. The world has gone black.

pm_activities: Reading the breakup letter; sitting alone in the Cabinet room.

politics.cabinet: Resignation of Fisher; Churchill leaving Admiralty.

pm_mood_witness: Margot: Henry looks like a man who has been shot. He can barely speak.

diaries_summary.excerpt: We have done it. He knows.
I found him with the letter in his hand. He said nothing, but I knew it was over.
